Barker, J.W.
Kisbey,
To Sask. - June, 1902.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure that name is correct or you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name
   J.W. BARKER

2. Your address
   Kisbey, Sask.

3. Date
   May 17/1912

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   Sunderland

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Aaron J. Barker

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   June 1902

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   Ontario, Canada

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   13 years old

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   To better our economic condition

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
    Government literature

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Wished me well

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With family

13. What means of transportation did you use?

CPR

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents etc.)

Pov into a ditch 7 degrees and 35 degrees at midnight at 10 o'clock at night. Spent 4 days in morgue bed in Regina. Waiting for twin to be born. Hot's conduct. Leaving home in October 14 miles west of Prince Albert.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Prince Albert

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Not sure

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Not sure

5 day blizzard March 1904

Wife left Max & Ellen Homestead until 9 new

Niiglen near Qu'Appelle 1907. Baffin here about 9 inches at

Niiglen in winter & early in spring. No trees or wind to blow snow
